articles.headline: Complaints Undermine Hip Device
articles.snippet: Zimmer Holdings, the nation’s biggest producer of orthopedic devices, says it will suspend sales of an artificial hip component that some doctors have complained was failing at a high rate.
articles.abstract: Zimmer Holdings, the nation’s biggest producer of orthopedic devices, says it will suspend sales of an artificial hip component that some doctors have complained was failing at a high rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zimmer Holdings, the nation’s biggest producer of orthopedic devices, says it will suspend sales of an artificial hip component that some doctors have complained was failing at a high rate.

articles.headline: The Road Ahead for Ford Is Full of Smaller Cars
articles.snippet: With gas at $4, Ford is redirecting billions of dollars to build more small cars in a move that Alan R. Mulally, Ford’s chief, hopes will help the automaker thrive, not just survive.
articles.abstract: With gas at $4, Ford is redirecting billions of dollars to build more small cars in a move that Alan R. Mulally, Ford’s chief, hopes will help the automaker thrive, not just survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich.  In recent months, as Ford Motor Company executives watched $4 a gallon gas and a softening economy take a growing toll on sales and market share, the chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, prodded his management team for answers.

articles.headline: Plan Would Use Antiterror Aid on Pakistani Jets
articles.snippet: The U.S. plans to shift nearly $230 million to upgrading planes that critics say are not used to fight terrorism.
articles.abstract: The U.S. plans to shift nearly $230 million to upgrading planes that critics say are not used to fight terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration plans to shift nearly $230 million in aid to Pakistan from counterterrorism programs to upgrading that country’s aging F-16 attack planes, which Pakistan prizes more for their contribution to its military rivalry with India than for fighting insurgents along its Afghan border.

articles.headline: Big Sensor a Small Step for Cameras
articles.snippet: Sigma develops a compact camera with a huge sensor. Let the euphoria begin? Not so fast...
articles.abstract: Sigma develops a compact camera with a huge sensor. Let the euphoria begin? Not so fast...
articles.lead_paragraph: Every camera manufacturer wants a bigger slice of that $42 billion digital-photography pie. So what do they do? They pile on bells and whistles. Smile recognition, anti-red-eye, blah, blah, blah.

articles.headline: An Investment Gets Trapped in Kremlin’s Vise
articles.snippet: The fall of one of Russia’s most prominent foreign investors points to the official corruption that afflicts the country.
articles.abstract: The fall of one of Russia’s most prominent foreign investors points to the official corruption that afflicts the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  William F. Browder was one of the most prominent foreign investors here, a corporate provocateur who brought the tactics of Wall Street shareholder activists to the free-for-all of post-Soviet capitalism. Until, that is, the Kremlin expelled him in 2005.

articles.headline: A State That Never Was in Wyoming
articles.snippet: A 1941 travel guide recounted the story of an audacious attempt by a group of would-be rebels to form a new state.
articles.abstract: A 1941 travel guide recounted the story of an audacious attempt by a group of would-be rebels to form a new state.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHERIDAN, Wyo.  In early 1939, as talk of war in Europe clouded the horizon and hard economic times gripped the nation, a group of business and political leaders in this northern Wyoming city hatched an audacious, if not quite ridiculous, plan to break off huge chunks of Wyoming, South Dakota and Montana and form a new state.

articles.headline: House Approves Sweeping Effort to Help Housing
articles.snippet: Citing the need to restore confidence in the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the president said he would set aside his objections to the legislation.
articles.abstract: Citing the need to restore confidence in the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the president said he would set aside his objections to the legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The House approved far-reaching government assistance on Wednesday for the nation’s housing market, including broad authority for the Treasury Department to protect the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies from collapse.

articles.headline: Oil Survey Says Arctic Has Riches
articles.snippet: The Arctic may contain as much as a fifth of the world’s yet to-be-discovered oil and natural gas reserves, according to a new U.S. Geological Survey forecast.
articles.abstract: The Arctic may contain as much as a fifth of the world’s yet to-be-discovered oil and natural gas reserves, according to a new U.S. Geological Survey forecast.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Arctic may contain as much as a fifth of the world’s yet to-be-discovered oil and natural gas reserves, the United States Geological Survey said Wednesday as it unveiled the largest-ever survey of petroleum resources north of the Arctic Circle.

articles.headline: Gassing Up With Garbage
articles.snippet: After years of false starts, a new industry selling motor fuel made from waste is getting a big push in the U.S., with the first commercial sales possible within months.
articles.abstract: After years of false starts, a new industry selling motor fuel made from waste is getting a big push in the U.S., with the first commercial sales possible within months.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of false starts, a new industry selling motor fuel made from waste is getting a big push in the United States, with the first commercial sales possible within months.

articles.headline: China Presses Hush Money on Grieving Parents
articles.snippet: Local governments have begun a campaign to buy the silence of parents whose children died in the earthquake.
articles.abstract: Local governments have begun a campaign to buy the silence of parents whose children died in the earthquake.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANWANG, China  The official came for Yu Tingyun in his village one evening last week. He asked Mr. Yu to get into his car. He was clutching the contract and a pen.
